key_points: Chris Wallace announced his departure from Fox News after 18 years during his last broadcast of Fox News Sunday.
Wallace stated his decision to leave was to 'try something new' and expressed excitement about joining CNN's planned streaming service.
His departure from Fox News coincides with the expiration of his contract as reported by Variety.
CNN released a statement from Wallace expressing his eagerness to explore streaming and the flexibility it offers for interviews and storytelling.
Fox News praised Wallace's contributions and stated that Fox News Sunday would continue with a rotation of anchors until a permanent host is found.
Wallace had expressed dissatisfaction with Fox's airing of Tucker Carlson's series 'Patriot Purge', which included conspiracy theories about the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
Wallace's colleague, Bret Baier, tweeted celebrating Wallace's legacy at Fox, while Tucker Carlson and other Fox personalities did not comment on his departure.
Wallace's exit is part of recent high-profile media changes, including Brian Williams leaving NBC and CNN firing Chris Cuomo.
Wallace has a reputation for tough interviewing and has moderated two presidential debates in 2016 and 2020.
Despite criticism, Wallace has defended his impartiality, arguing that CNN and MSNBC also have opinion-based programming that pushes a liberal agenda.
